generif.text: The EVI1 gene locus was rearranged in all 13 myeloid malignancies patients and was associated with EVI1 overexpression. In 9 out of 13 patients, the 17q breakpoints clustered in a 250 kb region on band 17q22 encompassing the MSI2 gene
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)
Clinical trial of gene-disease association and gene-environment interaction. (HuGE Navigator)
Observational study of gene-disease association, gene-environment interaction, and pharmacogenomic / toxicogenomic. (HuGE Navigator)
Msi2 expression is not only highly upregulated during human chronic myeloid leukemia progression but is also an early indicator of poorer prognosis
MSI2 has a crucial role in both normal and malignant hematopoiesis.
High MSI2 is associated with acute myeloid leukemia.
Overexpression of MSI2 resulted in a decrease in MSI1 expression.
Down-modulation of MSI2 is associated with myelodysplastic syndromes and acute myeloid leukemia.
MSI2 is associated with shorter overall survival in acute myeloid leukemia patients.
a large set of SOX2-associated proteins in DAOY medulloblastoma cells
Data suggest that high MSI2 expression could indicate poor prognosis and facilitate risk and treatment stratification in adult BCR-ABL-negative B-cells acute lymphoblastic leukemia (B-ALL).
Report a statistical difference between the MSI2 gene expression in different gastric tumor grades, of note between grade I and grade II.
The Msi2 plays an important role in leukemogenesis involving the MAPK signaling pathway, which indicates that Msi2 may be a novel target for leukemia treatment.
MSI2 correlates with epithelial-mesenchymal transition and has the potential to be a new predictive biomarker of hepatocellular carcinoma prognosis and invasion.
These results confirm the association of MSI2 expression with outcome in adult B-ALL and demonstrate the utility of MSI2 as a clinical prognostic biomarker.
Up-regulated MSI2 is associated with more aggressive chronic myeloid leukemia.
Msi proteins contribute to an epithelial gene expression program in neural and mammary cell types.
Acute myeloid leukemia patients have a higher level of MSI2 gene expression.
MSI2 controls efficient translation of the oncogenic leukemic stem cell self-renewal program.
the MSI2 RNA-binding protein has a role in transformation of intestinal epithelium
This review highlights both the essential contribution of RBPs to posttranscriptional regulation and the importance of the Musashi family as master regulators of male gamete development--{REVIEW}

Concomitant loss of function of both MSI1 is sufficient to abrogate the growth of human colorectal cancer cells, and Msi gene deletion inhibits tumorigenesis in several mouse models of intestinal cancer.
our study indicates that MSI-2 overexpression is associated with an unfavorable prognosis and may be a potential biomarker for liver metastasis in colorectal cancer patients.
These results indicate that the human MSI2 gene might be a susceptibility gene for schizophrenia and encourage future research on the functional relationship between this gene and schizophrenia.
High Musashi2 expression is associated with pancreatic cancer.

MSI2 directly attenuates aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AHR) signalling through post-transcriptional downregulation of canonical AHR pathway components in cord blood haematopoietic stem and progenitor cells

The notion that regular and close monitoring of MSI2 mRNA levels in chronic myeloid leukemia patients might identify patients at risk of progressing to blast crisis was not supported by this study; an increase in MSI2 transcripts does not precede an increase in BCR-ABL1 mRNA levels.
MSI2 provides essential support for TGFbetaR1/SMAD3 signaling and contributes to invasive adenocarcinoma of the lung and may serve as a predictive biomarker of NSCLC aggressiveness
Overexpression of Msi2 significantly increased and silencing of Msi2 reduced the phosphorylation of JAK2 and its downstream effecter STAT3.

MSI2 expression was markedly increased in both PDAC cell lines and human PDAC specimens, and high MSI2 expression was associated with poor prognosis for PDAC. Forced MSI2 expression promoted PDAC proliferation, migration, and invasion in vitro and growth and metastasis in vivo, whereas knockdown of MSI2 expression did the opposite. Dysregulated KLF4/MSI2 signaling promotes PDAC progression and metastasis.
our findings identified a novel regulatory mechanism of MSI2 as an upstream regulator of ESR1 and revealed the clinical relevance of the RNA-binding protein MSI2 in breast cancer.
MSI2 overexpression induces paclitaxel resistance in ovarian cancer.
MSI2 might play a crucial role in sustaining stemness and chemoresistance of liver cancer stem cells in LIN28A-dependent manner in hepatocellular carcinoma.
these findings provide evidence that DBC2 suppresses tumorigenesis in breast cancer by ubiquitinating MSI2.
MSI2 and FLT3 are significantly co-regulated in human AML

MSI1 and MSI2 bind and regulate the mRNA stability and translation of proteins operating in essential oncogenic signaling pathways..This review provides a current overview of Musashi as a cancer driver and novel therapeutic target.
MSI2 regulates myeloid leukemia stem cells gene expression.
Differential methylation of the MSI2 gene (chr17:55484635) in blood and islet cells is strongly related to hyperglycemia.
Results provide evidence that MSI2 variants may contribute to the age-at-onset in schizophrenia.

Here, the authors demonstrate that the canonical Musashi2 isoform is subject to regulated site-specific phosphorylation, converting Musashi2 from a repressor to an activator of target mRNA translation.
High MSI2 expression is associated with esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.
MSI2 expression is increased in epithelial cells adjacent to breast carcinoma, and increases with increasing proximity.
PLAG1 and USF2 cooperation is thus an important contributor to stem cell-specific expression of MSI2 and hematopoietic stem and progenitor cell-specific transcriptional circuitry.

We report novel associations between methylation at MSI2 and LARS2 and obesity-related traits. These results provide further insight into mechanisms underlying obesity-related traits, which can enable identification of new biomarkers in obesity-related chronic diseases.
This provides proof of concept for the development of Gn-lip as a molecular therapy for colon cancer with MSI1/MSI2 overexpression.
Multiple MSI2-regulated mRNAs have been identified, and evidence has been provided that MSI2 controls IL6ST activity that control oncogenic signaling networks.

This study demonstrated that MSI2 is present in an oligomeric state in Alzheimer's disease brains compared to the age-matched non-demented subjects and that these large assemblies co-localize with tau contributing to the neurodegenerative pathogenesis.

Authors found that DANCR was distributed mostly in the cytoplasm and DANCR functioned as a miRNA sponge to positively regulate the expression of musashi RNA binding protein 2 (MSI2) through sponging miR-149 and subsequently promoted malignant phenotypes of bladder cancer cells, thus playing an oncogenic role in bladder cancer pathogenesis.
Study determined that both USP10 and MSI2 proteins are upregulated in colon cancer cells. MSI2 expression and stability are regulated by USP10 via deubiquitination of Lys-48.

HMGA2 knockdown regulates autophagy via MSI2-Beclin1 interactions to inhibit NF1 Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumours (MPNSTs)growth, revealing potential therapeutic targets for these untreatable tumours.

Knockdown of MSI2 induced downregulation of KRAS, and overexpression of MSI2 upregulated KRAS without causing an increase in the level of KRAS mRNA in bladder cancer. These results indicated that MSI2 post-transcriptionally regulated KRAS expression. Furthermore, MSI2 positively regulated KRAS expression through directly binding to the target sequence UAGUA in the 3'UTR region of KRAS mRNA.
ETV4 regulates MSI2 transcription by directly at the promoter region. ETV4 exerts oncogenic roles via regulating MSI2 in lung adenocarcinoma.
The results illustrate a possible mechanism of neurodegeneration mediated by the aggregation of MSI2 proteins and TauO, suggesting that MSI2 plays a critical role in cellular dysfunction.
Crystal and solution structures of human oncoprotein Musashi-2 N-terminal RNA recognition motif 1.
Interplay between the RNA binding-protein Musashi and developmental signaling pathways.

our results indicate that upregulation of miR-143-3p suppresses the progression of papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) by impeding cell growth, invasion, and migration via downregulation of MSI2, highlighting the potential of miR-143-3p as a target for future PTC treatment.

Study demonstrated the high expression of MSI2 in prostate cancer and inhibition of the proliferation of prostate cancer, even castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC) with MSI2 deletion. Knockdown of MSI2 was accompanied by significantly lower mRNA transcription and protein expression of AR and downstream molecules. Mechanistically, MSI2 binds the 3'-UTR of AR mRNA, and increases AR mRNA stability.
The correlation with Cyclin-D1 expression suggests an indirect role that MSI2 might have in the proliferation of Oral Squamous Cell Carcinoma cells.

Our results demonstrated that MSI2 maintained the stemness of CD44v6+ LCSCs by activating Notch1 signaling through the interaction with LFNG, which could be a potential molecular target for stem cell-targeted therapy for liver cancer.
MicroRNA-149 suppresses the malignant phenotypes of ovarian cancer via downregulation of MSI2 and inhibition of PI3K/AKT pathway.
Knockdown of Musashi RNA Binding Proteins Decreases Radioresistance but Enhances Cell Motility and Invasion in Triple-Negative Breast Cancer.

Study reveals a unique MUSASHI-2 (MSI2) mRNA binding network in hematopoietic stem cells that changes during transition to multipotent progenitors and discovers a significant increase in RNA binding activity of MSI2 in leukemic stem cells compared with normal hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells, resulting in selective regulation of MSI2's oncogenic targets.
RNA-binding protein MSI2 isoforms expression and regulation in progression of triple-negative breast cancer.
Knockdown of MSI2 inhibits metastasis by interacting with caveolin-1 and inhibiting its ubiquitylation in human NF1-MPNST cells.
LncRNA DANCR regulates osteosarcoma migration and invasion by targeting miR-149/MSI2 axis.
Musashi2 promotes the progression of pancreatic cancer through a novel ISYNA1-p21/ZEB-1 pathway.
Integrated genetic and epigenetic analyses uncover MSI2 association with allergic inflammation.
RNA-binding proteins Musashi and tau soluble aggregates initiate nuclear dysfunction.
Musashi 2 influences chronic lymphocytic leukemia cell survival and growth making it a potential therapeutic target.
Myofibroblast-Specific Msi2 Knockout Inhibits HCC Progression in a Mouse Model.
MUSASHI-2 confers resistance to third-generation EGFR-tyrosine kinase inhibitor osimertinib in lung adenocarcinoma.
Prognostic role and biologic features of Musashi-2 expression in colon polyps and during colorectal cancer progression.
Assessment of MUSASHI 1 and MUSASHI 2 expression in spermatozoa and testicular tissue.
MSI2 expression in adrenocortical carcinoma: Association with unfavorable prognosis and correlation with steroid and immune-related pathways.
Dual Knockdown of Musashi RNA-Binding Proteins MSI-1 and MSI-2 Attenuates Putative Cancer Stem Cell Characteristics and Therapy Resistance in Ovarian Cancer Cells.

Overexpression of lncRNA HCP5 in human umbilical cord mesenchymal stem cell-derived exosomes promoted the proliferation and inhibited the apoptosis of ovarian granulosa cells via the musashi RNA-binding protein 2/oestrogen receptor alpha 1 axis.
Theoretical studies on RNA recognition by Musashi 1 RNA-binding protein.
TP53 mutations and RNA-binding protein MUSASHI-2 drive resistance to PRMT5-targeted therapy in B-cell lymphoma.
The TGF-beta/Smad2/3 signaling pathway is involved in Musashi2-induced invasion and metastasis of colorectal cancer.
Prognostic value of MSI2 expression in human malignancies: A PRISMA-compliant meta-analysis.
Dysregulated Stem Cell Markers Musashi-1 and Musashi-2 are Associated with Therapy Resistance in Inflammatory Breast Cancer.
Clonal evolution dissection reveals that a high MSI2 level promotes chemoresistance in T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia.
Musashi-2 potentiates colorectal cancer immune infiltration by regulating the post-translational modifications of HMGB1 to promote DCs maturation and migration.

interpro.desc: RNA-binding protein Musashi homologue, RNA recognition motif 2

name: musashi RNA binding protein 2

reactome.name: Signaling by Rho GTPases, Miro GTPases and RHOBTB3

summary: This gene encodes an RNA-binding protein that is a member of the Musashi protein family. The encoded protein is transcriptional regulator that targets genes involved in development and cell cycle regulation. Mutations in this gene are associated with poor prognosis in certain types of cancers. This gene has also been shown to be rearranged in certain cancer cells. [provided by RefSeq, Apr 2016].
